<td class="rowhead1" width="15%">Summary</td><td colspan="99" width="85%">This course engages students with the fundamental principles of Structural Mechanics relevant to civil and mechanical engineers. Specific topics including: equilibrium, stress, strain, axial load, torsion, bending, shear, and deflections in structural elements including beams, columns, struts, ties, and trusses.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="rowhead1" width="15%">Course description</td><td colspan="99" width="85%">
    
    Lecture Topics:<br/>
<br/>
- T1 Introduction and Overview: Course structure and organisation. What is structural mechanics?  <br/>
- T2 Structural forms: Structural elements and examples. Strength and stiffness. Loads and factors.<br/>
- T3 Global Equilibrium: Forces and moments, point and distributed loads. Support conditions. Global equilibrium of structures. Concept of structural determinacy and indeterminacy.<br/>
- T4 Free Body Diagrams and Stress Resultants<br/>
  Truss equilibrium. Stress resultants in struts (axial load), shafts (torsion), beams (shear and bending) and pressure vessels (membrane forces).<br/>
- T5 Members carrying Axial Load<br/>
  Simple mechanical behaviour. Deformation (due to load and thermal strain).<br/>
- T6 Members carrying Torsion<br/>
  Torsion of circular shafts and other closed sections. Torsional stiffness and deformation.<br/>
- T7 Stress Resultants in Determinate Beams (1)<br/>
  Sign conventions. Shear force and bending moment diagrams.<br/>
- T8 Stress Resultants in Determinate Beams (2)<br/>
  Relationships between w, V, and M<br/>
- T9 Bending of Beams (1)<br/>
  Euler Beam Theory. Curvature. Plane sections. Bending strains<br/>
- T10 Bending of Beams (2)<br/>
  Euler Beam Theory. Elastic bending stresses. The neutral axis. Moment - curvature - stress - strain relationships.<br/>
- T11 Deflection of Beams<br/>
  Double integration of curvature to find deflection. Support boundary conditions. Beam stiffness<br/>
- T12 Superposition of Deflection<br/>
  Deflection coefficients. Superposition of deflections.<br/>
- T13 Geometric Section Properties<br/>
  Area, 2nd moments of area, Parallel axis theorem. Rectangular, circular, T and I sections<br/>
- T14 Composite Beam Sections<br/>
  Modular ratio and equivalent section. Stress and strain diagrams.<br/>
- T15 Shear Stresses in Beams (1)<br/>
  Complimentary shear. Derivation of shear stress formulae.<br/>
- T16 Shear Stresses in Beams (2)<br/>
  Shear flow. Rectangular, box and flanged sections.<br/>
- T17 Combined Loading<br/>
  Combining axial, torsion, shear and biaxial bending stresses.<br/>
- T18 Stress and Strain Transformation<br/>
  Plane stress, plane strain. Mohr's circle.<br/>
<br/>
Tutorials:<br/>
- 9 'Tutorials' (Format to be decided)<br/>
<br/>
Laboratory experiments:<br/>
- 4-6 'Physical Experiments/Demonstrations' (Format to be decided)
    
    
</td>
</tr>

<table class="sitstablegrid">
<caption>Learning Outcomes</caption>
<tr>
<td>
    On completion of this course, the student will be able to:
    <ol style="font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit;">
<li>Describe and manipulate fundamental concepts of stress, strain, and deformation in members carrying axial, bending, shear, and torsional loads;</li><li>Determine how statically determinate trusses and beams carry load; for beams using diagrams of bending moment and shear force, and evaluate the resulting elastic deflections of the beams;</li><li>Analyse structural cross sections, so as to determine the elastic stress and strain distributions, as well as the deformations, resulting from axial, bending and torsional actions;</li><li>Describe and manipulate relevant concepts of combined loadings and stress and strain transformation.</li>
</ol>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
